<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 170, 905, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 570, 612]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 847, 728, 864]]<|/det|>
This document has 16 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|> A student wishes to measure accurately the volume of approximately \(40 \text{cm}^3\) of water. She has two measuring cylinders, a larger one that can hold \(100 \text{cm}^3\), and a smaller one that can hold \(50 \text{cm}^3\). The water forms a meniscus where it touches the glass. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 127, 665, 312]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 322, 845, 341]]<|/det|> Which cylinder and which water level does the student use to ensure an accurate result? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 351, 541, 481]]<|/det|>
cylinderwater level
Alarger onebottom of meniscus
Blarger onetop of meniscus
Csmaller onebottom of meniscus

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 280, 834, 299]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 310, 485, 329]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 571, 90]]<|/det|> A gymnast jumps down from a high piece of apparatus. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 489, 120]]<|/det|> She gradually bends her knees as she lands. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 133, 356, 149]]<|/det|> Which effect does this have? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 161, 134, 178]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 160, 643, 178]]<|/det|> She will have a smaller change of momentum as she lands. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 187, 131, 204]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 186, 531, 203]]<|/det|> She will lose less kinetic energy as she lands. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 212, 131, 230]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 211, 648, 228]]<|/det|> She will exert a smaller impulse on the ground as she lands. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 238, 133, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 237, 692, 255]]<|/det|> She will experience a smaller force from the ground as she lands. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 284, 94, 301]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 282, 920, 315]]<|/det|> The table gives four energy resources and states whether the main source of energy for the resource is the Sun. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 327, 297, 345]]<|/det|> Which row is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 357, 631, 502]]<|/det|>
energy resourcemain source of energy is the Sun
Ageothermalyes
Boilno
Cwater held behind a damyes
Dwindno

liquid to solidliquid to gas

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Extremely small pollen grains in water are viewed through a microscope. The grains are seen to move continually and randomly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 504, 135]]<|/det|>
What is the reason for this random movement?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 144, 134, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 144, 650, 163]]<|/det|>
The grains are moved by randomly moving water molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 171, 134, 190]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 170, 700, 189]]<|/det|>
The grains are moved by random convection currents in the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 198, 134, 217]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 197, 685, 216]]<|/det|>
The grains are moved by random rays of light reflecting off them.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 223, 134, 242]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 222, 680, 241]]<|/det|>
The grains are moved by the random motion of their own atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 510, 106, 527]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 920, 542]]<|/det|>
A teacher shows his class a polystyrene cup. The polystyrene is a thick plastic with lots of tiny air bubbles in it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 555, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
He asks the class why the cup is so good at keeping a hot drink warm. Three suggestions are made.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 599, 625, 616]]<|/det|>
1 It contains air which is a poor thermal conductor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 626, 789, 644]]<|/det|>
2 The air is trapped in tiny bubbles so very little convection is possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 653, 551, 670]]<|/det|>
3 The plastic is a poor thermal conductor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 682, 379, 699]]<|/det|>
Which suggestions are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 708, 134, 727]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 708, 240, 727]]<|/det|>
1, 2 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 708, 300, 727]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[318, 708, 425, 727]]<|/det|>
1 and 2 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 708, 470, 727]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 708, 593, 727]]<|/det|>
1 and 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 708, 636, 727]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 708, 710, 727]]<|/det|>
2 and 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 803, 88]]<|/det|> Two samples of the same material have the same mass but different surface areas. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 860, 119]]<|/det|> Each sample is heated to the same temperature and then left to cool to room temperature. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 623, 149]]<|/det|> Each sample is allowed to cool to the same final temperature. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 158, 710, 266]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 280, 920, 312]]<|/det|> Which row correctly compares the decrease in internal energy and the initial rate of cooling for each sample? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 323, 833, 453]]<|/det|>
decrease in internal energyinitial rate of cooling
AX loses more internal energy than YX cools down faster than Y
BY loses more internal energy than XY cools down faster than X
CX and Y lose the same quantity of energyX cools down faster than Y
DX and Y lose the same quantity of energyY cools down faster than X
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 479, 107, 497]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 479, 791, 497]]<|/det|> In which type of wave is the direction of vibration parallel to the direction of travel? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 509, 343, 526]]<|/det|> A electromagnetic waves <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 536, 292, 552]]<|/det|> B seismic P-waves <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 562, 292, 578]]<|/det|> C seismic S-waves <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 588, 260, 603]]<|/det|> D water waves <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 631, 107, 650]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 631, 710, 650]]<|/det|> Waves in a ripple tank are diffracted as they pass through a narrow gap. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 661, 675, 678]]<|/det|> What can be done to make the spreading due to diffraction greater? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 689, 134, 707]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 689, 710, 707]]<|/det|> Decrease the frequency of the waves and keep the speed constant. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 715, 134, 733]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 715, 710, 733]]<|/det|> Decrease the speed of the waves and keep the frequency constant. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 742, 133, 761]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 742, 700, 759]]<|/det|> Increase the frequency of the waves and keep the speed constant. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 769, 133, 787]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 769, 662, 785]]<|/det|> Increase the frequency of the waves and decrease the speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 628, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 470, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 373, 260, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 403, 288, 460]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 373, 426, 392]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 403, 453, 460]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[571, 373, 591, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 403, 616, 460]]<|/det|>

The control room sends a message back to the vehicle telling it to stop. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 329, 920, 362]]<|/det|> What is the minimum time that elapses between the vehicle sensing the obstacle and receiving the message back from the control room? The diagram shows a simple a.c. generator. The magnet rotates around a fixed coil wound round a fixed iron core. The electromotive force (e.m.f.) output is a sine wave, a series of crests, zeros and troughs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 920, 166]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 917, 92]]<|/det|> A galaxy at a distance of \(3.1 \times 10^{21} \text{km}\) is moving away from the Earth with a speed of \(7000 \text{km/s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 920, 139]]<|/det|> What is the Hubble constant \(H_0\) calculated using this data and what is the speed of a galaxy at a distance of \(6.2 \times 10^{21} \text{km}\) from the Earth? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 149, 504, 293]]<|/det|>
